title: Ralph Northam
added: Virginia was the 23rd state to expand the possibility of parole to juveniles serving life sentences.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/virginia-finally-recognizes-that-children-jailed-for-life-deserve-at-least-a-chance-for-parole/2020/02/27/9d025bd4-58be-11ea-9000-f3cffee23036_story.html|author=''The Washington Post'' Editorial Board|title=Virginia finally recognizes that children jailed for life deserve at least a chance for parole|work=The Washington Post|date=February 27, 2020|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://eji.org/news/virginia-abolishes-life-without-parole-for-children/|title=Virginia Abolishes Life Without Parole for Children|work=[[Equal Justice Initiative]]|date=February 25, 2020|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref>

title: Ralph Northam
added: During Virginia's 2020 legislative session, there was discussion among Democrats about the possibility of fully reinstating parole, which the state had abolished in 1995 under its then governor [[George Allen (American politician)|George Allen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/advocates-see-best-opportunity-to-enact-liberal-criminal-justice-reform-in-va-in-a-generation/2019/12/26/d358acc0-2276-11ea-a153-dce4b94e4249_story.html|author=Justin Jouvenal|title=Advocates see best opportunity to enact liberal criminal justice reform in Va. in a generation|work=The Washington Post|date=December 26, 2019|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-abolished-parole-25-years-ago-now-efforts-to-restore-it-are-advancing/2020/02/01/c36c85ae-4218-11ea-b5fc-eefa848cde99_story.html|author=Antonio Olivo|title=Virginia abolished parole 25 years ago. Now efforts to restore it are advancing.|work=The Washington Post|date=February 1, 2020|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref>

title: Ralph Northam
added: During Virginia's 2020 legislative session, there was discussion among Democrats about the possibility of fully reinstating parole, which the state had abolished in 1995 under its then-governor [[George Allen (American politician)|George Allen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/advocates-see-best-opportunity-to-enact-liberal-criminal-justice-reform-in-va-in-a-generation/2019/12/26/d358acc0-2276-11ea-a153-dce4b94e4249_story.html|author=Justin Jouvenal|title=Advocates see best opportunity to enact liberal criminal justice reform in Va. in a generation|work=The Washington Post|date=December 26, 2019|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-abolished-parole-25-years-ago-now-efforts-to-restore-it-are-advancing/2020/02/01/c36c85ae-4218-11ea-b5fc-eefa848cde99_story.html|author=Antonio Olivo|title=Virginia abolished parole 25 years ago. Now efforts to restore it are advancing.|work=The Washington Post|date=February 1, 2020|accessdate=September 20, 2020}}</ref>

title: Ralph Northam
added: Another reform enacted by Northam in 2020 eases the petition process for writs of [[actual innocence]].<ref name="takes action"/>

title: Ralph Northam
added: Another reform enacted by Northam in 2020 eases the petition process for[[writs]]of [[actual innocence]].<ref name="takes action"/>

title: Ralph Northam
added: In April 2020, Northam signed a bill that expanded the conditions under which fines and court costs can be paid for with community service credits; Virginia law had previously allowed these credits to be earned only before or after incarceration. The reform enacted by Northam in 2020 allows these credits to be earned during incarceration as well.<ref name="takes action"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wusa9.com/article/features/producers-picks/northam-marijuana-virginia-legislation/65-50960d97-9278-4d58-a8cc-db342a5c0359|author=Kyley Schultz|title=Simple possession of marijuana decriminalized in Virginia, prior conviction records now sealed|work=[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA]]|date=April 16, 2020|accessdate=October 29, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jurist.org/news/2020/04/virginias-governor-signs-multiple-progressive-bills-in-to-law/|author=Matthew Fischer|title=Virginia governor signs criminal justice reform bills into law|work=[[JURIST]]|date=April 14, 2020|accessdate=October 29, 2020}}</ref>
